item.title: Dalian Atkinson: PC guilty of former footballer's manslaughter
item.description: Dalian Atkinson's family says "the whole country now knows the truth" about how he died.

item.title: Covid: Push to close gap in vaccine uptake
item.description: More walk-in slots will be available as the UK reports 16,135 daily cases, a rise of nearly 5,000.

item.title: HMS Defender: Russian jets and ships target British warship
item.description: More than 20 jets and two coastguard ships shadow HMS Defender as it sails near Crimea's coast.

item.title: Queen describes Matt Hancock as 'poor man' at meeting with PM
item.description: The monarch made the remarks at her first in-person weekly meeting with the PM since lockdown began.

item.title: Covid-19: Jab uptake rising in ethnic minority groups and travel industry protests
item.description: Five things you need to know about the coronavirus pandemic this Wednesday evening.

item.title: Boris Johnson dismisses rape concerns as jabber, says Labour
item.description: No 10 insists Boris Johnson was accusing Labour of talking rather than taking action, at PMQs.

item.title: US migrant camp 'kids feel like they're in prison'
item.description: More than 2,000 migrant children are being detained in an overcrowded camp in Texas ridden with disease.

item.title: Travel industry protests against Covid restrictions
item.description: Airline and travel firms want more help from the government amid tight rules on international travel.

item.title: Exams altered next year after pandemic disruption
item.description: Gavin Williamson says 2022 A-levels and GCSEs in England are likely to be modified for lost lessons.

item.title: Harrison Ford injures shoulder on Indiana Jones 5 film set
item.description: The 78-year-old actor injures his shoulder while rehearsing a fight scene in the UK.

item.title: Jadon Sancho: Manchester United increase offer for Borussia Dortmund winger to £72.6m
item.description: Manchester United increase their offer for Jadon Sancho to 85m Euros (£72.6m) but it is still short of Borussia Dortmund's valuation of the England winger.

item.title: Rembrandt's The Night Watch painting restored by AI
item.description: The canvas was trimmed in 1715 to fit between two doors in Amsterdam’s city hall.

item.title: Education interrupted: Kashmir students climb mountain to cross digital divide
item.description: Students in a remote village in the Himalayas struggle to access the internet in order to take classes.

item.title: Bee-eater birds spotted in 'magical' sighting in Great Yarmouth
item.description: The European bee-eaters are spotted on land behind a retail park in Great Yarmouth, Norfolk.

item.title: Giant panda gives birth to twins at Tokyo's Ueno Zoo
item.description: The cubs, which have not yet been named, are the first ever twins to be born at the zoo in Tokyo.

item.title: In pictures: Tartan Army's rollercoaster ride
item.description: Scotland fans endure joyous highs and familiar lows as the Euros campaign ends in defeat by Croatia.

item.title: Lego plans to sell bricks from recycled bottles in two years
item.description: Firm says challenge is to make more environmentally friendly bricks strong enough to build Hogwarts.

item.title: The 99-year-old charity shop volunteer refusing to slow down
item.description: David Flucker volunteers in a charity shop four days a week - and has no plans to give it up any time soon.

item.title: CEO Secrets: 'My billion-pound company has no office'
item.description: How Britain's youngest billionaire works differently - setting his firm up to thrive in lockdown.

item.title: What is different about the new £50 banknote?
item.description: A behind-the-scenes look inside a high-security banknote printing plant.

item.title: Leicester postman returns Father's Day letter sent to heaven
item.description: The eight-year-old girl has been posting letters to her dad, who passed away when she was four months.

item.title: Wind turbines: How UK wants to become 'Saudi Arabia of wind'
item.description: With Britain's offshore wind power capacity growing at speed, we see how huge turbines are installed.

item.title: The Papers: Foreign travel hope, and 'no Indyref2 before 2024'
item.description: A mix of stories lead Wednesday's front pages, including fresh hopes for changes to travel rules.

item.title: Sonic the Hedgehog: 'I'd never seen anything like it in a video game'
item.description: Tom Kalinske, one of the men responsible for gaming's most loveable hedgehog, speaks to Newsbeat.

item.title: Windrush Day: 'Windrush is the big thing in the black community'
item.description: Avril Nanton and Jody Burton have released a book looking at London's black history.

item.title: Bobby Zamora scores spectacular goal for friend's team in Colchester
item.description: The ex-Premier League player was spotted playing for a friend's team in Colchester

item.title: Wymondham mechanic finds python under bonnet during MOT
item.description: The snake named Gav, which belongs to the vehicle's owners, had been missing for two weeks.

item.title: Wally the Walrus takes a nap on Isles of Scilly fishing boat
item.description: The walrus took to a local fishing boat for a spot of sunbathing in the Isles of Scilly.

item.title: Brexit: How many more EU nationals in UK than previously thought?
item.description: Five years on from referendum, it turns out there were far more EU nationals in the UK than was thought.

item.title: PMQs: Fact-checking the debate over low rape prosecution levels
item.description: The level of rape prosecutions dominated early exchanges at Prime Minister's Questions.

item.title: Britney Spears: Singer's conservatorship case explained
item.description: The ongoing arrangement has sparked a public backlash from fans who support the #FreeBritney movement.

item.title: Time: How realistic is the BBC prison drama?
item.description: From blackmail to bullying, those with experience of the inside unpick the hard-hitting BBC drama.

item.title: Pentagon UFO report: Here's what we know
item.description: A new report is expected to reveal what the US military knows about unexplained flying objects.

item.title: Elephants' 500km-trek across China baffles scientists
item.description: Scientists are surprised by how far they've gone and say they're displaying other unusual behaviours.

item.title: 'Heartbreaking' conditions in US migrant child camp
item.description: An investigation by the BBC has uncovered alarming conditions at a child migrant camp in Texas.

item.title: Hungary's anti-gay law threatens programming of TV favourites
item.description: International condemnation grows towards a Hungarian law banning depiction of homosexuality to under-18s.

item.title: GP data sharing: What is it and can I opt out?
item.description: A scheme to centralise GP patient records in England has been delayed after concerns about a lack of publicity.

item.title: The trainer boss who even has a pair for funerals
item.description: Richard Johnson of Foot Locker has a pair of trainers for every occasion - even weddings and funerals.

item.title: A fake wedding, and a $250,000 scam
item.description: How a British man's dreams of a future with his Ukrainian fiancee ended in financial disaster.

item.title: What is white privilege?
item.description: A new education report by a group of MPs has caused debate because of references to white privilege.

item.title: Slovakia 0-5 Spain: Luis Enrique's side progress to last 16
item.description: Spain earn their first win at Euro 2020 in style as they thrash Slovakia to set up a last-16 tie with Croatia.

item.title: New Zealand beat India to win World Test Championship
item.description: New Zealand are crowned the first Test world champions after completing a stunning win over India on a dramatic sixth day of the final.

item.title: Sweden 3-2 Poland: Emil Forsberg scores twice as Sweden knock Poland out of Euro 2020
item.description: Poland produce a dramatic comeback from 2-0 down against Sweden but it is not enough as they exit Euro 2020 after finishing bottom of Group E.

item.title: Euro 2020: Slovakia's Martin Dubravka's 'totally bizarre' howler gives Spain the lead
item.description: After a Pablo Sarabia effort rattles the crossbar from 25 yards out, goalkeeper Martin Dubravka punches the rebound into his own net giving Spain a 1-0 lead against Slovakia in Seville.

item.title: Euro 2020: Robert Lewandowski denied twice by the woodwork
item.description: Striker Robert Lewandowski is denied the chance to become Poland's top goalscorer, hitting the bar twice in quick succession against Sweden in Saint Petersburg.

item.title: Vaccine passports: How can I prove I've had both my Covid jabs?
item.description: People who've had both Covid jabs may soon be able to avoid quarantine after travel.

item.title: Euro 2020: Why are England players self-isolating?
item.description: Two England players are self-isolating after a Scotland player tested positive for Covid.

item.title: Covid-19 in the UK: How many coronavirus cases are there in my area?
item.description: Explore the data on coronavirus in the UK and find out how many cases there are in your area.

item.title: Covid: Ivermectin to be studied as possible treatment in UK
item.description: Scientists begin to give the drug to people at home with symptoms to see if it can keep them out of hospital.

item.title: What are the rules for travelling to green, amber and red list countries?
item.description: The government is considering allowing double vaccinated adults to avoid quarantine after travel.

item.title: Covid: What's the roadmap for lifting lockdown?
item.description: Coronavirus restrictions are staying in place because of concerns about the Delta variant.

item.title: How much is Covid costing the UK and how will we pay?
item.description: The pandemic is costing the government hundreds of billions of pounds but where will it all come from?

item.title: Euro 2020 and Covid: How can I watch with my friends?
item.description: Covid rules are making things a bit different for Euro 2020 spectators.

item.title: Covid: When will I get the vaccine?
item.description: Over 40s in England and Scotland can have their second dose after eight weeks instead of 12.

item.title: Coronavirus: Where does the government borrow billions from?
item.description: How does it work when a government wants to borrow money, and when does it have to pay it back?

item.title: Covid map: Coronavirus cases, deaths, vaccinations by country
item.description: Key maps and charts explaining how the virus has spread around the world.

item.title: Covid: What are the care home visiting rules?
item.description: New guidance gives hope to people who want to go to see their loved ones.

item.title: Covid: Should I be working from home or going back to the office?
item.description: As lockdown restrictions ease gradually across the UK, what are the rules about returning to work?

item.title: What are the social distancing rules and when could they end?
item.description: Will we still need to be socially distanced through the summer? A social distancing review is advising the government.

item.title: Covid vaccines: How fast is progress around the world?
item.description: Charts and maps tracking the progress of Covid vaccination programmes.

item.title: Can we dance outside at our wedding? And other questions
item.description: We answer some of your questions about England's roadmap out of lockdown, and other Covid-related issues.

item.title: Ros Atkins On… How the Delta variant took hold in the UK
item.description: Ros Atkins traces back the story of the Delta variant and how it delayed the UK’s reopening plans.

item.title: What are the rules for pubs, restaurants, festivals and gigs?
item.description: The lifting of restrictions is being delayed, which could affect planned events

item.title: What are the rules for weddings and receptions?
item.description: Restrictions on weddings have been eased across the UK - so how can you now celebrate?

item.title: Covid vaccine: How many people in the UK have been vaccinated so far?
item.description: The logistics of vaccinating millions of people across the country, as more than 43 million people receive at least one dose.

item.title: Covid: What do over-18s need to know about the vaccine?
item.description: The vaccine rollout is now available for younger adults. What do they need to know about getting jabbed?

item.title: Tokyo Olympic Games: When are they and will they go ahead despite Covid?
item.description: The Tokyo Summer Olympics are due to start in July, despite a surge in Covid cases in Japan.

item.title: Covid symptoms: What are they and how do I protect myself?
item.description: A new cough, fever and change in smell or taste are the key symptoms that mean you may have coronavirus.

item.title: Covid: Which areas are being surge tested for variants?
item.description: People who live, work or travel in various parts of the UK are being urged to get a Covid test.

item.title: UK holidays: When and where can I go... and who with?
item.description: Going abroad is not straightforward, so many people are opting to stay in the UK for their holidays.

item.title: Coronavirus: When can we stop wearing face masks or face coverings?
item.description: Wearing a face covering is currently a legal requirement in many places, but could the rules change as lockdown eases further?

item.title: China fails to meet promises on missing Xinjiang children
item.description: China made a public pledge to help find Kalbinur Tursan's children but she may never see them again.

item.title: The Lazarus heist: How North Korea almost pulled off a billion-dollar hack
item.description: In 2016 North Korean hackers planned a $1bn raid on Bangladesh's national bank and came within an inch of success. But how did they do it?

item.title: Daniel Morgan: Last chance for family in Britain's most-investigated, unsolved murder
item.description: The death of Daniel Morgan is Britain's most investigated unsolved murder. His family believe police corruption, and reluctance to confront it, could explain the murder and the failed investigations

item.title: Troubled US teens left traumatised by tough love camps
item.description: Paris Hilton is among thousands who allege abuse at programmes aimed at reforming US teenagers.

item.title: Living with obesity: The people who are hard-wired to store fat
item.description: Specialist health professionals say obesity should be regarded as a complex illness, and people with the condition shouldn't be blamed for it.
